problem_text:
In any group G, the cosets of all of its normal subgroups together with the empty set form the block lattice C(G) with respect to inclusion, which, for infinite |G|, is subdirectly irreducible and, for finite |G| ⩾ 3, is even simple (D. M. Smirnov, A. V. Reibol’d, Algebra and Logic, 23, no. 6 (1984), 459–470). How large is the class of such lattices? Is every finite lattice embeddable in the lattice C(G) for some finite group G?
D. M. Smirnov
answer: For each g ∈ G the filter {x ∈ C(G) | g ∈ x} is modular (and even arguesian); the variety generated by the block lattices of groups does not contain all finite lattices (D. M. Smirnov, Siberian Math. J., 33, no. 4 (1992), 663–668).
